body: IMHO we need to rely only on ephemeral nodes in ZK. I went through a similar discussion with @cheddar  a few weeks ago related to storing QTL states in ZK and I'm in agreement with him that ZK should be completely droppable (meaning we shouldn't need to do regular backups of ZK to keep the cluster stable).

Can we clarify under which conditions and at what level the timeout is not honored?

Can you describe the bug that you are seeing in more detail?
can you also make sure that we have a serde test for AlphaNumericsTopNMetricSpec
done

IIRC in QTL, you were trying to store the lookup tables in zookeeper, 
here we are storing the transient status of the tasks running on different nodes instead of permanent lookup tables. 

I initially tried using announcer or persistentEphermal node in which the worker can recreate the status node after ZK disconnection, but the issue there is that the communication of status is not one way the status are being announced by the MM and then finally removed by overlord. 
when using persistentEphermal nodes MM has no knowledge of whether the status is being read by the indexer or not and again recreates the status whenever the overlord removes the status. 

I had a discussion with @gianm on this and it came out it might make more sense for the overlord to be the **only** thing that deletes the status, and for it to _not_ be an ephemeral node
so instead of detecting dead tasks through disappearance of an ephemeral status node, the overlord could detect it through disappearance of worker announcement node and overlord to do the cleanup after a grace period.
+1, LGTM

The main problem I see with adding a second thread pool where queries are waiting, is that we cannot guarantee that resulting yielders will always get closed, some of them may get discarded without being consumed, even if we cancel the future. If we don't close yielders, resources will not get released.

The other issue is that in the event of a large query backlog, we may potentially be creating hundreds of threads, since the pool in unbounded. Creating threads is expensive, so this will cause strain on the system, and compound the backlog even more.

A simpler solution might be to register the queries with the QueryManager before submitting them to the processing pool, and have the query processing ensure that already cancelled queries get interrupted before they even start doing any work as they are taken from the backlog.

is it possible to benchmark random skips instead of fixed size strides? That might be more representative of actual workload. It could be that using fixed size strides the cpu is much better at predicting acesss patterns into the uncompressed array. Also, please share the jvm version you are using for the benchmarks.

This PR addresses the failures with current way communication through Zookeeper nodes, 
Ideally in future we should move the task assignment and status announcements out of zookeeper, 
created a feature request here for moving the communication out of zookeeper -  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1420

the slowness was with filteredServerViewInventory test, 
we were adding announcing a segment which was expected to be filtered by the filteredServerview and then were waiting for timeout(1 min) ensuring that the filtered segment never gets added. 

In the modification I added a counter which gets incremented every time a the serverView receives an event for update, and now the test waits only until the filterServerView receives the expected event and asserts that the segment was not added

@fjy JMH has different ways of benchmarking, you can use throughput (number of operations per time unit) or average (average time per operation). The score will depend on the method chosen. In this case the score is average time, with the unit of the score being microseconds per operation. An operation is an execution of the benchmark method. Error is the 99.9% confidence interval around that score.

:+1: I'm in general agreement with the changes here. It would be nice to make tasks more restartable in the future. I think when we rework segments announcements to use a gossip protocol or something that doesn't involve ZK, the same logic can be used for tasks. For hadoop index tasks, a restart of the task can just mean starting things over. For a realtime index task, the task can behave the same way as a realtime node restarting. This of course, requires the realtime index task to read from Kafka. I think more discussions and proposals and required for those changes. Just some food for thought right now.

In general we're trying to move away from having injectors be injected. Is it possible to accomplish this without directly injecting an injector?

@drcrallen Why are you trying to move away from that?  Was that direction discussed on the mailing list?  I think I missed the thread...

In this case, it's possible that the thing is dynamically injecting a different annotation, I believe the only way to accomplish that is with injecting the injector (which should be a fairly safe thing as long as it is done "correctly")
We have two +1s and the changes here are generally uncontroversial in what was changed in the code, so I merged.
s'cool

I was asked to put in a bit more context on when it is ok to inject the injector.  There was a comment I made on another PR made by @drcrallen 

> One of the primary benefits of DI is that you get objects which are defined in terms of their dependencies. This constructor is making the statement that a KafkaExtractionManager depends on the entire global state of the process (i.e., the Injector), which is incorrect.
> 
> The proper way to work with DI is to define the object depending directly on its dependencies and then setup your bindings so that the proper things get sent in

I made this comment because `KafkaExtractionManager` is a class that is business logic.  It is something that would exist even if we weren't using Guice for DI.  In that case, building the dependency on the `Injector` means that `KafkaExtractionManager` can only ever be instantiated with Guice.  It also means that the Guice injector passed in must be able to create whatever instances that `KafkaExtractionManager` _might_ ask for, which can be a moving target.  Given that it is business logic, it should only really depend on other business logic objects.  If we wanted to replace Guice with something else, it would be annoying to tease apart this chunk.

In this case, we are dealing with `AbstractHttpClientProvider` which is a Guice `Provider` instance.  Meaning that it is used by the Guice subsystem in order to inject an `AbstractHttpClient`.  The business logic piece (`AbstractHttpClient`) depends on other business logic objects, but in order to connect up the various dependencies correct, we need the `injector` in the `Provider`.  In this case, the `injector` is being used by Guice and never leaks out of the Guice system.  So, even if we were to swap out Guice, it would mean that this `Provider` would go with it so it wouldn't be a problem.

In general, it should always be possible to "new" up business logic objects.  Once you get that setup done, then you go to your DI system (Guice in our case) and figure out how to make DI do the right thing.

Hopefully that makes more sense now?

At a high level, will this only work if there is only one worker per host?
yeah, the current RTR is structured around using worker.getHost() as a key for identifying a worker and assumes it will be unique for every worker.
Just a clarification.  What do we expect to happen if ZK completely dies and has to be restarted without any of the old state?  Will things break irreparably?

In case of a complete ZK state cleanup, the overlord will not have knowledge of any tasks running on the workers, and it will end up assigning tasks to the workers and the workers will end up assigned more tasks than the capacity allocated for a while.
I think this has been answered, so I am going to close this. Please reopen if not.
